summary: invasive diagnostic methods should be performed with caution in the intensive care unit. it would be helpful if the prevalence, risk factors, and clinical impact of virus detection are elucidated. respiratory viruses are well-known for their high prevalence in patients with community acquired pneumonia (CAP) who exhibit milder clinical presentations. however, only limited data exist regarding the prevalence of respiratory viruses among healthcare associated pneumonia (HCAP) and hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) patients. the institution used the Seeplex Respiratory Virus Detection assay (Seegene Inc., Seoul, Korea) from 2008 to 2014, the anyplexTM II RV16 with Tagging Oligonucleotide Cleavage and Extension technology was used. the RV16 uses 16 primer sets for the simultaneous detection of 16 respiratory viruses. patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, asthma, bronchiectasis, pneumoconiosis, and tuberculosis destroyed lung were defined to have chronic lung disease [15–17] patients with and without virus detection were compared in terms of their baseline demographics, laboratory results, and clinical outcomes. all statistical analyses were performed using IBM SPSS software (version 22.0; IBM Corp., Armonk, NY), and graphs were created using Prism 5 software (GraphPad software, San Diego, CA) a two-tailed P-value of less than 0.05 was considered statistically significant. this assay is based on the multiplex PCR method. it uses a dual priming oligonucleotide system. it detects influenza virus types A and B, parainfluenza virus types 1, 2, and 3, RSV types A and B, adenovirus, metapneumovirus, coronavirus 229E, NL63 and OC43, and rhinovirus. patients with and without virus detection were compared in terms of baseline demographics, laboratory results, and clinical outcomes. patients with and without virus detection showed no significant differences in terms of age, sex, and disease severity, which was presented as the APACHE II score. seasonality was more prominent with CAP, compared to HCAP and HAP. clinical outcomes, such as the length of hospital stay, length of ICU stay, and in-hospital mortality, did not differ between the two groups.
